ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Protecting public health and the environment is what the Fresno-Clovis Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility is all about.  The Fresno-Clovis Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility is operated by the City of Fresno and provides wastewater treatment services for the greater Fresno metropolitan area.



On an average day, the Fresno-Clovis Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility in Fresno, California, receives 58 million gallons of wastewater - enough to cover a football field to a height of more than 15 stories. If you live in Fresno, Clovis or some areas of Fresno County, you produce part of that wastewater.



The average American produces about 183 gallons of wastewater every day from toilets, showers, washing machines and many other domesti

c sources. And that's not counting the millions of gallons of wastewater produced by businesses and industries throughout the Fresno metropolitan area.



The Fresno-Clovis Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility is located at Jensen and Cornelia in southwest Fresno. Wastewater generated from homes and businesses in the metro area travels through 1700 miles of sanitary sewer lines to the Wastewater Treatment Facility. Treatment consists of two major steps; primary and secondary treatment, and a process to treat solids removed in the process at the plant.



The Fresno-Clovis Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility has a permitted capacity to treat 91.5 million gallons a day (mgd) of wastewater. Toxic materials and even too much water can hamper the treatment of wastewater. Minimizing harmful chemicals helps keep our biological process healthy, allowing us to adequately clean the water. Limiting the use of water allows us to continue to use present facilities and delays the need to further expand our facility, keeping sewer rates low for the community.



The Fresno-Clovis Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  Fresno-Clovis Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility's safety and environmental policies are administered by the Wastewater Manager, who conducts periodic inspections of the facility to ensure compliance, and oversees the entire safety and environmental programs, including the CalARP Program.  



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The Fresno-Clovis Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility is located at 5607 W. Jensen Avenue in Fresno, California, which is located approximately 2 miles south of Highway-180 and 6 miles west of Highway-41. The area immediately surrounding the facility is rural. 



The primary business of Fresno-Clovis Regional Wastewa

ter Treatment Facility is to treat wastewater. In order to conduct operations, the facility maintains 13 Anaerobic Digesters that are used to digest processed primary and secondary sludge/scum. Microbes in the Digesters digest organic materials to generate digester gas which is comprised of approximately 60% methane. A maximum of approximately 18,052 pounds of methane, a regulated substance, is at the facility at one time. The system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, generates methane from the digesting process. Typical operating conditions range from 6.5" water column on the low pressure methane side to 10" water column on the high pressure methane side of the Digesters. The Conditioning Plant pressures range from -1 psig suction on the lower pressure side to 188 psig discharge on the high pressure side.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



In order to operate the system, the facility complies with the Cal-OES California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.



The Fresno-Clovis Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility methane system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, the Fresno-Clovis Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility operates in accordance with the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  It is important to note that the methane system has been designed with several safety features to prevent the accidental release of methane. For example, Digester Gas pressures are maintained below their inline Pressure Vacuum Relief Valve (PVRV) settings of 10.0" of water column. The Digester #7 PVRV is maintained at 10.0" of water column and used as a secondary pressure relief for the Dystor unit.



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The CalARP Program defines "accident" as the following:



"An unanticipated emission of a regulated substance or other extremely hazardous

substance into the ambient air from a stationary source."



The release must have caused at least one of the following:



?    On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (19CCR2750.9(a)); or

?    Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (19CCR2750.9(a))."



Based on the above definition and an investigation into the facility's accident history conducted during the PHA meeting on September 17, 2020, there have been no releases of methane in the past five years (September 2015 - September 2020).



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The facility has an Emergency Action Plan (plan) in effect.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:  



?    save lives;

?    minimize and avoid injuries;

?    protect the environment; and

?    minimize property damage.



The Plan provides the response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, methane health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This Plan is reviewed and updated as needed. This Plan was reviewed and updated to ensure compliance with the PSM, RMP, and CalARP regulations.  



Fresno-Clovis Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility personnel circulate throughout the plant, taking note of unusual conditions in any portion of the system.  In the event that a methane leak is discovered, the person nearest to the leak will alert any personnel in the immediate area who are unaware of the danger and the Fresno-Clovis Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility Wastewater Manager.  The Wastewater Manager will determine what procedures and personnel are necessary to remedy the problem. Emergency agencies will also be notified as necessary as outlined in the Emergency Action Plan.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



The Process Hazard Analysis, performed on September 17, 2020, generated mitigation measures (recommendations) to improve

safety at the Fresno-Clovis Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility located in Fresno, California.  The mitigation measures include additional training, key maintenance-related tests/inspection, and enhanced emergency response policies and procedures.  The Fresno-Clovis Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility safety committee is planning to complete several items, including the recommendations, over the next year, as a continual effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:



1. Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.



2. Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.



3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.



4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.



EXTERNAL EVENTS



External events were considered during the HAZOP as any type of catastrophic failure (i.e. line break).  Catastrophic failures encompass the following external events: meteorite impact, missile impact, sabotage, and war.  A catastrophic line failure of the methane system could result in a line break which were examined in the Hazard Assessment report.  The following are some of the external events examined in this study.  





Sabotage



The facility is surrounded by a fence and operators are present onsite 24/7. In addition, the facility is also equipped with security cameras.  The Fresno-Clovis Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility has no history with any type of sabotage and the facility is unaware of any sabotage activities in the area.



Extreme Temperatures



External events including various weather conditions were also considered during the HAZOP.  High summer temperatures were considered under the guide words "More Pressure" and "More Temperature".  Similarly, low winter temperatures were considered under the guide words "Less Temperature" and "Less Pressure".  The lowest temperature recorded

in Fresno was 17 ?F (January, 1913) while the highest temperature recorded was 115 ?F (July, 1905).  Although various weather conditions are common experiences at the facility, they are not considered to be a contributing factor to hazardous material accidents in California.  For incidents where the weather condition was identified, clear weather was reported for 90% of the incidents.  The remaining 10% of the incidents occurred during rain (4%), fog (3%), other (2%) which includes snow, hail and electrical storms, and the unknown category (1%). 



Flooding



According to the Climate Diagnostic Center, most of the rainfall in Fresno, California occurs during the winter months, while the summer seasons are nearly rainless. On November 16-17, 1900, 2.86 inches of precipitation fell in Fresno, which was the wettest day in Fresno history.  Heavy rainfall and flooding have not been a safety concern for the Fresno-Clovis Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility. In the event of flooding, the methane system could be manually shut down until conditions warrant returning to normal operations.



Fire



Fires were considered under the guide words "More Pressure" and "More Temperature" during the HAZOP study.  The facility is mostly constructed of concrete and steel. In the event of a fire, the pressure relief valves would relieve the excess pressure by venting methane into the atmosphere.  In addition, the system is located outside decreasing the likelihood of a fire affecting the system.



Extreme Winds



The methane equipment is located outdoors.  The equipment is designed for rugged conditions, utilizing durable construction materials such as steel.  Methane equipment at the site is not anticipated to be affected by strong winds.  Strong winds are most likely to disrupt the facility's electrical supply.  In the event that the facility loses electrical power, the methane system will shut down.  Operators will reset the system once power is restored.

These items (Management of Change, Pre-Startup Safety Review, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, etc.) have been developed for the Fresno-Clovis Regional Wastewater Treatment Facility and will be implemented when required.  In addition, the Emergency Action Plan outlines notification procedures and reporting procedures in the event of an emergency, which could include fire, methane release, blackout, and earthquake.
